Introduction

Contraceptive counseling should be patient-centered and take into consideration patient-specific factors (eg, medical history), the risk/benefit profiles of various contraception methods, and the patient's future fertility desires.

Combined estrogen/progestin oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)

Mechanism of action



OCPs prevent pregnancy through several mechanisms:



  • Ovulation inhibition (primary mechanism of contraception):  The constantly elevated systemic levels of estrogen exert negative feedback on both the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary, which inhibits the release of gonadotropins (LH, FSH).  This suppression prevents the midcycle LH surge required for ovulation.
  • Cervical mucus thickening:  due to the progestin component; the increased cervical mucus viscosity prevents sperm passage.
  • Endometrial changes:  The progestin component thins the endometrial lining, making it less suitable for implantation (this mechanism is also utilized for the management of patients with heavy menses).
  • Decreased fallopian tube peristalsis:  due to the progestin component; the decreased peristalsis limits oocyte transport and helps prevent fertilization.

Efficacy



With perfect use (taken at the same time every day without missing any doses), OCPs are >99% effective; but with typical use (including missing doses or taking at inconsistent times), they are 91% effective.



The efficacy of OCPs can be influenced by factors such as gastrointestinal disturbances (eg, vomiting or diarrhea) and interactions with other medications (eg, antibiotics, anticonvulsants) that increase liver microsomal enzyme activity.

Adverse effects



While OCPs are generally well tolerated, the elevated systemic estrogen levels they cause can lead to a range of adverse effects (

):



Common adverse effects (most common during the first few months of use)



  • Nausea, bloating
  • Breast tenderness
  • Headaches
  • Breakthrough bleeding
  • Mood changes


Serious adverse effects



  • Venous thromboembolism (VTE):  particularly in patients with additional risk factors (eg, prior VTE, immediately postpartum)
  • Arterial thromboembolism:  risk of myocardial infarction and stroke, particularly in women age â‰¥35 who smoke cigarettes
  • Hypertension:  small (3-5 mm Hg) systolic increase due to increased angiotensinogen synthesis by estrogen during hepatic first-pass metabolism
  • Hepatocellular adenoma

Contraindications



Due to the risk of serious adverse effects of increased estrogen, particularly the increased risk of thromboembolism, cardiovascular disease, stroke, breast cancer, and liver disease, the following are contraindications to OCP use (

):



Absolute contraindications



  • Prior venous thromboembolism
  • Thrombophilia (eg, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome)
  • Migraine with aura
  • Prior stroke or ischemic heart disease
  • Severe hypertension
  • Active liver disease
  • Current or past breast cancer
  • Age â‰¥35 and â‰¥15 cigarettes/day
  • <3 weeks postpartum


Relative contraindications



  • Age â‰¥35 and <15 cigarettes/day
  • Mild or medication-controlled hypertension
  • Inherited thrombophilia carrier (and family member with thrombophilia plus thromboembolism)

Noncontraceptive benefits



  • Regulation of menstrual cycles:  provide predictable menstrual periods with decreased menstrual bleeding and decreased symptoms of dysmenorrhea (eg, bloating, cramping).
  • Treatment of premenstrual syndrome (PMS) and premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD)
  • Management of benign gynecologic conditions


  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS):  treats irregular menses, hirsutism, and acne (due to estrogen component increasing sex hormone binding globulin [SHBG], which reduces serum androgen levels).
  • Endometriosis:  can reduce pain and the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus.


  • Reduces the risk of ovarian and endometrial cancer:  due to inhibition of ovulation and thinning the endometrium.

Special considerations



  • In postpartum patients, OCPs should not be started until >21 days after delivery to mitigate the risk of VTE.  In addition, in women who are breastfeeding, OCPs should not be started until at least 6 weeks postpartum due to possible impact on breastmilk production.

Progesterone-only contraceptive pills



Progesterone-only contraceptive pills (POPs), also known as "mini pills," are a form of hormonal contraception that are particularly useful for women who cannot take estrogen-containing contraceptives.

Mechanism of action



POPs prevent pregnancy primarily through increasing the viscosity of cervical mucus, making it difficult for sperm to penetrate and reach the egg.  This mechanism has a relatively short duration of action (<20 hours), followed by a rapid return to fertility.



Compared to other forms of high-dose progestin or combination estrogen-progestin contraceptives, POPs are not reliable at inhibiting ovulation.

Efficacy



POPs are effective when taken correctly, with an efficacy of approximately 98% with perfect use.  However, for most patients, typical use has an efficacy of approximately 91%; this is due to the short duration of action of the pill, inconsistent administration schedule, and missed doses.  In addition, the efficacy of POPs can be influenced by factors such as gastrointestinal disturbances (eg, vomiting, diarrhea) and interactions with other medications (eg, anticonvulsants, antibiotics).

Adverse effects



POPs are generally well tolerated, but adverse effects include:



  • Irregular menstrual bleeding (eg, spotting, breakthrough bleeding, or amenorrhea)
  • Acne
  • Mood changes

Contraindications



Certain medical conditions and risk factors contraindicate the use of POPs:



  • Pregnancy
  • Active liver disease
  • Current or past breast cancer
  • Prior stroke or ischemic heart disease
  • Undiagnosed abnormal uterine bleeding
  • History of malabsorptive bariatric surgery

Special considerations



POPs are particularly suitable for certain populations:



  • Postpartum patients:  can be initiated immediately postpartum and can be used in breastfeeding women because they do not affect milk production and have no adverse effects on the infant.
  • Women with contraindications to estrogen


However, because POPs have such a short duration of action, they should be given only to patients who can take a daily pill with consistent timing (same time every day).  Patients who cannot take a daily pill or have irregular schedules should be counseled on another form of contraception.

Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate intramuscular injection



The depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) intramuscular (IM) injection is a long-acting progestin-only contraceptive method (commonly known as Depo-Provera) that is administered every 3 months.

Mechanism of action



The depot medroxyprogesterone IM injection prevents pregnancy through several mechanisms:



  • Inhibiting ovulation (primary mechanism):  inhibits the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone from the hypothalamus, which decreases secretion of gonadotropins (LH,FSH), and prevents the midcycle LH surge needed for ovulation.
  • Thickening of cervical mucus:  increases the viscosity of cervical mucus, making it difficult for sperm to penetrate and reach the egg.
  • Endometrial changes:  thins the endometrial lining, making it less suitable for implantation of a fertilized egg.

Efficacy



With the depot medroxyprogesterone IM injection, perfect use is approximately 99% effective and typical use is approximately 94% effective; this discrepancy is due to potential treatment delays in receiving the injection every 3 months (eg, missed appointments).

Adverse effects



Although depot medroxyprogesterone IM injection is generally well tolerated, it can cause a range of adverse effects:



Common adverse effects



  • Irregular menstrual bleeding (eg, spotting, breakthrough bleeding), with approximately 50% of patients developing amenorrhea after a year
  • Weight gain (high-dose progesterone stimulates appetite)
  • Fatigue, nausea
  • Injection site reaction


Serious adverse effects



  • Decreased bone mineral density:  Long-term use of DMPA can reduce bone mineral density; however, it is generally reversible after discontinuation.

Contraindications



Certain medical conditions and risk factors are contraindications to the use of DMPA, including:



  • Pregnancy
  • Current or past breast cancer


In addition to these contraindications, patients with the following conditions should be counseled on the risks of DMPA use:



  • Active liver disease
  • Current or past breast cancer
  • Ischemic heart disease, atherosclerosis
  • Severe hypertension
  • Diabetes mellitus with vascular complications
  • Osteoporosis or significant risk factors (eg, chronic systemic glucocorticoid use) due to the risk of decreased bone mineral density with long-term use.

Noncontraceptive benefits



In addition to its use for pregnancy prevention, DMPA is used for a variety of gynecologic conditions due it commonly causing amenorrhea.  Commonly treated conditions include:



  • Abnormal uterine bleeding (particularly with concomitant iron deficiency anemia)
  • Endometriosis
  • Patients with cognitive impairment or decreased mobility that makes menstrual hygiene difficult to maintain

Special considerations



Medroxyprogesterone IM injection is particularly suitable for certain populations:



  • Postpartum patients:  can be initiated immediately postpartum and can be used in breastfeeding women because it does not affect milk production and has no adverse effects on the infant.
  • Women with contraindications to estrogen
  • Women seeking long-term contraception


In contrast, DMPA may not be appropriate for the following patient populations:



  • Patients who desire fertility within a year of starting contraception:  After stopping DMPA, there can be a delay in the return to normal ovulatory cycles and fertility, often taking several months to a year.


  • Patients who may have difficulty maintaining routine healthcare appointments (eg, unreliable transportation, inability to take time off work).  DMPA injections are required every 3 months, and delays in injection increase the risk of pregnancy.
  • Patients with osteoporosis or significant risk factors for low bone density (eg, chronic systemic glucocorticoid use):  due to the risk of decreased bone mineral density with long-term DMPA use.  If this is the best contraceptive option, these patients should be counseled on regular exercise, vitamin D and calcium supplementation, and avoiding tobacco and alcohol use.

Progestin-releasing subdermal implant



The progestin subdermal implant (

figure 1
) is a highly effective, long-acting, reversible contraceptive that provides extended protection against pregnancy.  It involves the insertion of a small, flexible rod containing progestin under the skin of the upper arm.

Mechanism of action



The progestin subdermal implant prevents pregnancy through 2 main mechanisms:



  • Thickening of cervical mucus and decreased tubal mobility:  Progestin increases the viscosity of cervical mucus, creating a barrier that impedes sperm penetration and motility.  In addition, progestin decreases fallopian tube mobility; the combination of these mechanisms decreases the ability of sperm to fertilize the egg.
  • Inhibiting ovulation:  the continuous release of progestin suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, preventing the midcycle surge of LH necessary for ovulation.

Efficacy



The progestin subdermal implant is one of the most effective contraceptive methods available, with perfect and typical use having a >99% effectiveness rate (because once placed, it is not user dependent).  The implant provides long-term contraception, typically effective for up to 3 years.

Adverse effects



While the progestin subdermal implant is generally well tolerated, it can cause some adverse effects, such as:



  • Irregular menstrual bleeding:  most common adverse effect; can include intermenstrual spotting, prolonged bleeding, and amenorrhea.
  • Headaches
  • Breast tenderness
  • Weight gain (average of 3 kg [6.6 lb] over the course of 3 years)
  • Acne

Contraindications



Certain medical conditions and risk factors contraindicate the use of the progestin subdermal implant, and include:



  • Pregnancy
  • Active liver disease
  • Current or past breast cancer
  • Undiagnosed abnormal uterine bleeding
  • History of thromboembolic disorders

Special considerations



The progestin subdermal implant is particularly suitable for certain populations:



  • Postpartum patients:  can be initiated immediately postpartum and can be used in breastfeeding women, as it does not affect milk production and has no adverse effects on the infant.
  • Women with contraindications to estrogen
  • Women seeking long-term contraception (particularly adolescents who would like long-term contraception but do not want a pelvic examination for intrauterine device placement)
  • Patients with cognitive impairment or decreased mobility that makes menstrual hygiene difficult to maintain

Intrauterine devices



Progestin-releasing and copper-containing intrauterine devices (IUDs) are long-acting reversible contraceptives that provide highly effective pregnancy protection.

Mechanism of action



Progestin-releasing IUDs (

figure 2
) prevent pregnancy through multiple mechanisms:



  • Cervical mucus thickening (primary mechanism):  creates a barrier which makes it difficult for sperm to enter the uterus.
  • Thinning of the endometrial lining:  makes the uterus less suitable for implantation.
  • Possible sperm inhibition:  creates an environment that is hostile to sperm, reducing their motility and ability to fertilize the egg.
  • Inhibiting ovulation (in a subset of users)


Copper-containing IUDs (

figure 3
) prevent pregnancy because the copper enhances the cytotoxic inflammatory response in the endometrium, causing endometrial inflammation that is toxic to both sperm and ova and impairs implantation.

Efficacy



IUDs are among the most effective contraceptive methods available, with both perfect and typical use having efficacy rates >99%.



The copper-containing IUD is effective up to 12 years and progestin-containing IUDs are effective between 3-8 years (depending on the dose of progesterone).  The efficacy rates do not change during that time, making them a good option for women seeking reliable, long-term contraception.

Adverse effects



While progestin-releasing IUDs are generally well tolerated, they can cause some adverse effects:



Common adverse effects of progestin-releasing IUDs



  • Irregular menstrual bleeding or spotting (especially in the first 3-6 months), followed by amenorrhea in approximately 20% of patients
  • Headaches
  • Mood changes


Common adverse effects of copper-containing IUDs



  • Increased menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea (especially in the first few months)
  • Irregular menstrual bleeding or spotting


Serious adverse effects of both types of IUDs



  • Uterine perforation:  a rare complication where the IUD perforates the uterine wall during insertion; the IUD must be removed.
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID):  increased risk during the first few weeks after insertion if there is an existing infection (patients typically undergo gonorrhea and chlamydia testing to help mitigate the risk).
  • Expulsion:  IUD may be partially or completely expelled from the uterus, often during the first year.
  • Risk of ectopic pregnancy:  There is an overall decreased pregnancy risk; if pregnancy does occur, the risk of ectopic pregnancy is increased due to the hostile uterine environment created by the IUD.

Contraindications



Contraindications to both copper-containing and progestin-releasing IUDs



  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Acute pelvic infection (eg, acute cervicitis, PID)
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Severe uterine cavity distortion


Contraindications specific to progestin-releasing IUDs



  • Current or past breast cancer
  • Active liver disease


Contraindications specific to copper-containing IUDs 



  • Wilson disease
  • Copper allergy
  • Severe dysmenorrhea and/or heavy menstrual bleeding (can be exacerbated)

Special considerations and noncontraceptive benefits



IUDs are good options for the following populations:



  • Patients seeking a long-acting, low-maintenance contraception:  once placed, IUDs remain effective several years (dependent upon the type and dose) and are not dependent on user reliability.  Once removed, fertility is immediately restored.
  • Patients who are breastfeeding and desire postpartum contraception:  Both types of IUDs can be placed during the immediate postpartum period.  They are safe for use during breastfeeding and do not affect milk production.
  • Patients who require emergency contraception:  both types of IUDs are effective methods of emergency contraception, and can remain in place for long-term contraception


Progestin-releasing IUDs are a good option for the following populations:



  • Patients with contraindications to estrogen
  • Patients with heavy menstrual bleeding and some cases of endometrial hyperplasia


Copper-containing IUDs are a good option for the following populations:



  • Patients with contraindications to estrogen and/or progesterone

Barrier contraception: condoms, cervical cap, and diaphragm

Mechanism of action



The various forms of barrier contraception (eg, condoms, cervical cap (

figure 4
), diaphragm (
figure 5
)) create a physical barrier that prevents semen from entering the uterus, thereby blocking sperm from reaching and fertilizing an egg.



Condoms have an added benefit of protecting against sexually transmitted infections because they also act as a barrier to pathogens, reducing the risk of transmission of HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis.

Efficacy



With perfect use, barrier contraception is 98% effective.  However, barrier contraception has the greatest typical use failure rate (approximately 80% efficacy), which is  due to a variety of factors:



  • For condoms, this is dependent on the condom being used correctly with every act of intercourse (ie, consistent use), with correct application and no breakage or slippage.


  • For cervical caps:  These must be inserted before intercourse and left in place for up to 48 hours, with no movement of the device.
  • For diaphragms:  These must be inserted before intercourse and left in place for 6-24 hours after intercourse.


The efficacy of all forms of barrier contraception is improved with concomitant use of spermicides.  Patients should be instructed to apply spermicide to the device before application/insertion and use additional spermicide with each act of intercourse.

Adverse effects



Male condoms are generally safe and well tolerated, but they can cause some adverse effects, including:



  • Allergic reaction to latex:  Latex is the most common material used in condoms; symptoms of allergic reaction can include itching, redness, and swelling.  Nonlatex options (eg, polyurethane, polyisoprene) are available for those with latex allergies.
  • Reduced sensation during intercourse:  This can affect sexual satisfaction and decrease use rate.


The cervical cap and diaphragm are also typically safe, but adverse effects can include:



  • Vaginal irritation
  • Urinary tract infections:  particularly with diaphragm use, as the device may exert pressure on the urethra.
  • Toxic shock syndrome:  Although rare, there is a risk of toxic shock syndrome if the device is left in place for >24 hours.

Contraindications



Male condoms are safe for most people, but an absolute contraindication to use is:



  • Latex allergy:  Individuals with a confirmed latex allergy should avoid latex condoms and use non-latex alternatives such as polyurethane or polyisoprene condoms.


Risk factors that contraindicate the use of the cervical cap and diaphragm include:



  • Allergy to spermicide or the device components
  • History of toxic shock syndrome
  • Frequent urinary tract infection

Special considerations



Because the cervical cap and diaphragm are reusable, and because there is risk of toxic shock syndrome, the devices must be cleaned and properly sanitized after each use.

Permanent contraception:  bilateral tubal ligation and vasectomy



Patients who desire permanent sterilization can undergo either bilateral tubal ligation or have their partner undergo vasectomy.  In both procedures, patients require extensive counseling on the permanence of the procedure and the risk of regret, particularly in young and/or nulliparous patients.

Mechanism of action and efficacy



In a bilateral tubal ligation, the fallopian tubes are either fully removed, have a section removed, or have a section occluded with either a surgical clip or via electrosurgical desiccation (ie, burning the tube to create an occlusion from the damaged tissue).  Patients are typically recommended to avoid intercourse for several weeks, which is likely due to a combination of postsurgical recovery in addition to time needed for procedure permanence.



In a vasectomy (

figure 6
), the vas deferens is transected bilaterally to block the transport of new sperm.  A vasectomy has no effect on existing sperm distal to the transection; a patient can still have viable sperm in the distal vas deferens for up to 3 months and at least 20 ejaculations following vasectomy.  Sexual intercourse can typically be resumed within a week following the procedure, but pregnancy is still possible due to residual sperm in the ejaculate.  Therefore, patients require serial semen analysis until azoospermia is confirmed, until which point they should use an additional form of contraception.

Special considerations



Permanent sterilization should not be performed in patients unsure about future fertility.  Though there are reversal procedures, the success rates of these procedures are small and decrease with time.
